Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to use computational models at different length scales to develop an understanding of how changes to the proteins that form the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) of the kidney alter the mechanical properties of the basement membrane as a whole. The GBM is the major structural layer of the filtration apparatus of the kidney, so its ability to withstand high pressures and allow blood plasma to pass through it is necessary for proper kidney function. A series of models from the molecular to the tissue scale will be constructed and linked together. The stiffness and strength of the tissue will be estimated based on the protein properties, as will the permeability of the tissue (i.e., its tendency to permit filtration flow through it). Finally, changes in the properties of the tissue, coupled with the known demand for filtration, will be used to model dynamic changes in the GBM in response to changes in load or protein properties.
If successful, these studies will help explain how the kidney, which filters 40-50 gallons of blood every day, performs in healthy conditions and suffers decreased performance in disease. The new understanding may help drive treatments for patients with genetic diseases that affect the kidney (e.g., Alport syndrome) and also for patients with kidney disease arising from other sources, such as diabetes. The project also involves training of a Ph.D. student in biomedical engineering and an outreach program for students interested in STEM at the College of the Menominee Nation, which will contribute to the strength and diversity of our high-tech workforce.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focused on the role of the glomerulus, a small complex unit within the kidney (there are about one million of them in each kidney). Blood plasma passes through the wall of the glomerulus and is then either recovered or sent off as urine. This project focused on the ability of the glomerulus to perform its filtering functions when changes occured to its underlying structure.

One of the major inspirations for this project was the experimental observation that molecules in the healthy glomerular capillary wall tend to coil around each other more than similar molecules in most other parts the body. This unique coiling phenomenon is believed to be important, and when the necessary molecules are not available because of genetic defect, a disease results (Alport syndrome).  The current project involved both experimental and computational studies exploring the ramifications of the coiling phenomenon.

Experimentally, we showed (Gyoneva et al., Exp. Eye Res., 113C:87, 2013) that the lens capsule of the eye, which is structurally similar to the glomerular capillary and contains the same coiling proteins, is more compliant in mice with Alport syndrome than in healthy mice. This distinction was, to our knowledge, the first mechanical measurement of the effect of Alport syndrome on a structure's behavior.

Theoretically, we developed a series of models (Gyoneva et al., Annals BME 43:1695, 2014; Gyoneva et al., Roy Soc Interface Focus 6:20150069, 2015; Bersie et al., in preparation) exploring how the presence or absence of coiling determines the ability of the glomerular capillary wall to function and regulate itself. We found that coiling is extremely important because it allows the tissue to maintain both permeability (to allow plasma to filter through it) AND strength (to withstand the pressures needed for filtration). The importance of coiling in maintaining proper function is an important consideration in the development of future therapies for Alport syndrome and kidney disease in general.

 


Last Modified: 03/20/2018
Modified by: Victor H Barocas

This project focused on the ability of the glomerulus to perform its filtering functions when changes occured to its underlying structure. One of the major inspirations for this project was the experimental observation that molecules in the healthy glomerular capillary wall tend to coil around each other more than similar molecules in most other parts the body. This unique coiling phenomenon is believed to be important, and when the necessary molecules are not available because of genetic defect, a disease results (Alport syndrome). The current project involved both experimental and computational studies exploring the ramifications of the coiling phenomenon. Experimentally, we showed (Gyoneva et al., Exp. Eye Res., 113C:87, 2013) that the lens capsule of the eye, which is structurally similar to the glomerular capillary and contains the same coiling proteins, is more compliant in mice with Alport syndrome than in healthy mice. This distinction was, to our knowledge, the first mechanical measurement of the effect of Alport syndrome on a structure's behavior. The importance of coiling in maintaining proper function is an important consideration in the development of future therapies for Alport syndrome and kidney disease in general.
